pullRequest.body:
This PR changes the notion of minimality from being a set with an unbundled relation `r` (i.e. having type signature `minimals (r : α → α → Prop) (s : Set α) : Set α`) to being a predicate with a bundled order relation in a typeclass:  `Minimal [LE α] (P : α → Prop) : α → Prop`.
It also does the same for maximality. 

This is hopefully an improvement, for a few reasons : 
* ergonomic API with dot notation (eg `Minimal.eq_of_le`, `Minimal.not_lt`), 
* no need to specify a particular relation explicitly (no use of `minimals`/`maximals` for a relation that was not defeq to `LE.le` currently appears anywhere in mathlib),
* the potential in future to unify ad hoc notions of min/maximality appearing in various locations in mathlib (eg `zorn_preorder`, `Sylow.is_maximal'` to name a couple of random examples). 

Since this change removes the definitions `minimals` and `maximals` and all their API, it required a total overhaul of the contents of `Order.Minimal`, and necessarily required updating all uses of `maximals`/`minimals` elsewhere. There were not all too many of these; this PR is designed to be the smallest it could be while making this change. 

The changes required outside `Order.Minimal` were: 

- redefinition of `Ideal.minimalPrimes` in `RingTheory/Ideal/MinimalPrime` to use `Minimal` rather than `minimals`, with the necessary minor changes to proofs that used the old definition, including in `AlgebraicGeometry/PrimeSpectrum/Basic`.
- redefinition of `irreducibleComponents` in `Topology/Irreducible` to use `Minimal` rather than `minimals`, with necessary minor changes to proofs that used the old definition. 
- updating of the maximality used in the definition of a matroid in `Data/Matroid/Basic` from `maximals` to `Maximal`, with the necessary changes to everywhere in `Data/Matroid/*` that a matroid was specified using the definition directly. 
- the necessary changes to two lemmas in `Data/Finset/Lattice` that used `minimals`/`maximals` in the statements. 

I attempted to clean up the API in `Order.Minimal` to work smoothly with the new definitions, but numerous judgment calls were needed; I removed a few lemmas about `maximals/minimals` that were used nowhere, and seemed unlikely to be useful with the new definition.

Comment is welcome!

---

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> Mathlib.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

> I've left a few minor comments, but overall, I think this is okay. That said, I have not thoroughly vetted the new API in comparison to the old one. My feeling is that it seems to work with what we have (in that nothing breaks), and that in the worst case, we can add some things later that are missing. On the other hand, this is not my area of the library, so I won't merge at this time.

Thanks for looking at this - I am sorry reviewing wasn't easier!
bors merge

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/10252856320/job/28364195347)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/10252856320/job/28364195145)

I've left a few minor comments, but overall, I think this is okay. That said, I have not thoroughly vetted the new API in comparison to the old one. My feeling is that it seems to work with what we have (in that nothing breaks), and that in the worst case, we can add some things later that are missing. On the other hand, this is not my area of the library, so I won't merge at this time.

The `_iff` part of the name is clearly implied here
```suggestion
@[simp] theorem minimal_toDual : Minimal (fun x ↦ P (ofDual x)) (toDual x) ↔ Maximal P x :=
  Iff.rfl

@[simp] theorem maximal_toDual : Maximal (fun x ↦ P (ofDual x)) (toDual x) ↔ Minimal P x :=
```
Can we have aliases for dot notation in both directions?
What's the point of these lemmas? The hypothesis implies `P = Q`, and in a proof you can use `convert` to get `∀ x, P x ↔ Q x` as a goal

Can you first prove the more general
```suggestion
@[simp] theorem maximal_subtype {x : Subtype Q} : Maximal (fun _ ↦ True) x ↔ Maximal (P ⊓ Q) x := by
```

Unnecessary brackets
```suggestion
theorem Minimal.and_right (h : Minimal P x) (hQ : Q x) : Minimal (fun x ↦ P x ∧ Q x) x :=
```

Can you first show the more general
```suggestion
theorem Minimal.mono (h : Minimal P x) (h : Q ≤ P) (hQ : Q x) : Minimal Q x :=
```

This lemma is really weird. Without even knowing what the definition of `Minimal` is, the LHS simplifies to
```suggestion
    Minimal P x ↔ (Minimal P x) ∧ Q x := by
```
Maybe just drop it?

In the abstract, it looks weird, but the intention here is that the lemma provides a motive for rewriting that would otherwise be annoying to write explicitly, say if you have an goal of the form `_ ∧ Q x ↔ Minimal (fun x ↦ P x ∧ Q x) x` and you want to reduce it to `Q x → ((Minimal P x) ↔ _)`, where `Q` and `P` have long statements.
(note that `rw [and_iff_left_of_imp]` wouldn't work in that example because of the binder, and `simp_rw [and_iff_left_of_imp _]` would require an annoying proof term if `P` and `Q` are complicated. )
Is `R x ∧ Q x ↔ Minimal (fun x ↦ P x ∧ Q x)` really such a common goal?
I'm not making a point purely on the basis of that goal (which was just an example), but that kind of thing has certainly come up for me.
I would like to see some concrete examples. I suspect there's a better(/more general?) lemma to be had

I think I've answered your question (it provides a motive for a rewrite), and I don't think it makes sense to ask for concrete examples when this is by definition new API. 

If you have an abstract lemma in mind, suggest it!
You are free to provide non-minimal concrete examples deep down in one of your repos if that makes it easier for you!

Any decision to remove or keep these lemmas is marginally impactful at best, and given that I earnestly anticipate them to be somewhat useful at least in my case, I'd rather just move forward with the PR than continue this discussion.

Unnecessary brackets
```suggestion
  obtain ⟨h | h, hmin⟩ := h
```
Can you make `not_minimal_iff` be the (currently missing) preorder version, and `not_minimal_iff_exists_lt` be this lemma?

```suggestion
alias ⟨exists_of_not_minimal, _⟩ :=not_minimal_iff
```

```suggestion
theorem minimal_congr_of_imp_of_forall (hPQ : ∀ ⦃x⦄, Q x → P x)
```
maybe? I'm not too attached
I think I prefer this way.
It's annoying that those lemmas don't apply to finset
I think this is out of scope - nothing about Finset was in the original file.
(I've added a TODO)

```suggestion
    Minimal P s ↔ P s ∧ ∀ x ∈ s, ¬ P (s.erase x) where
  mp h := ⟨h.prop, fun x hxs hx ↦ by simpa using h.le_of_le hx (erase_subset _ _) hxs⟩
  mpr h := ⟨h.1, fun t ht hts x hxs ↦ by_contra fun hxt ↦
    h.2 x hxs <| hP ht (subset_erase.2 ⟨hts, hxt⟩)⟩
```

```suggestion
  simp_rw [maximal_iff, and_iff_right hB, and_imp, forall_exists_index]
```

When doing a refactor, adding unnecessary changes is *not* helping. I understand that your PR is motivated by applications in matroid theory, but I don't need to see the changes in an already big diff to be convinced.

You have already added them here, so I won't ask you to revert, but this is typically the kind of changes that can/should be left to a separate PR.

```suggestion
  exact ⟨J, ⟨hJmax, hX⟩, hJ⟩
```

```suggestion
```

```suggestion
  (indep_aug : ∀ ⦃I B⦄, Indep I → ¬ Maximal Indep I →
```

```suggestion
```
(I assume those are typos? since a refactor is not really the place to orthogonally prettify proofs)

There are two `p` in context
```suggestion
  {p | Minimal (fun q ↦ q.IsPrime ∧ I ≤ q) p}
```

Sorry, but this diff is really hard to read. I cannot assert whether the former API was preserved. Would you please split this PR into
1. A PR solely adding new API and reproving the existing API using it. This demonstrates that the new API is at least as powerful as the old one.
2. A PR replacing all uses of the old API by the new API
3. A PR deprecating the old API

Possibly, PRs 2 and 3 can be made into a single one, but for readability PR 1 should be separate.

You are departing in tone from what one would normally consider a 'review'. But I will make a PR of the form (1.) as you suggest. 

Also, for the benefit of anyone doing a refactor, I think that guidelines like your comment should be available in advance somewhere easily accessible to anyone making a PR. I think that in this case, such a small refactor could easily be done in one PR without adverse consequences; learning that things should be done a certain way as a matter of policy shouldn't be so ad hoc.

They certainly do not *have* to be this way, but my experience is that you get much better feedback (both from Lean and from the reviewers) when you do things the way I explain above. Indeed, I basically came up with that method of proceeding and I don't think anyone but me has seriously used it in mathlib refactors yet.

This `show` is not pretty. You could do: `← funext (@Set.mem_setOf_eq _ · Ideal.IsPrime)`, but I think it would be better to add the `rfl` lemma:
```lean
import Mathlib.Data.Set.Basic

example {α : Type u} {p : α → Prop} :
    (fun a ↦ a ∈ {x : α | p x}) = p :=
  rfl
```
I opted for the former, because it looks to me like `mem_setOf_eq` should really be phrased as the lemma you suggest in the first place, and it wouldn't be the right place here to make that change.
why are there random blank lines floating around here? And why are some added?
like here?
or here?
please fix these unless you have a good reason to have them, and if so, please explain. It's just distracting otherwise. I will stop marking them all.

I've tried to revert to the way things were. I tend to include blank lines to separate ideas in proofs, and when I was rewriting to work with the new API, I didn't faithfully preserve where the blanks were.

@apnelson1 if you feel there is a separate enough flow ‌/ idea in the proof which is not otherwise captured by the structure of the proof, that's a sign that you should add a *comment* instead of a blank line.

This is the main change that worries me here (all the others look great), in particular this forbids us from (conveniently) talking about minimality with respect to a relation that isn't the default ordering on the type... For the moment, perhaps it's enough to add a TODO saying that this case might need further consideration?
Thanks - I've added this TODO to the docstring.

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - refactor(Order/Minimal): change minimality to a predicate

source.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat(Order/Zorn): change zorn to use Maximal API

nodes.body: I've left a few minor comments, but overall, I think this is okay. That said, I have not thoroughly vetted the new API in comparison to the old one. My feeling is that it seems to work with what we have (in that nothing breaks), and that in the worst case, we can add some things later that are missing. On the other hand, this is not my area of the library, so I won't merge at this time.

source.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat(Combinatorics/SimpleGraph/Matching): Add matching free graphs

nodes.body:
> I've left a few minor comments, but overall, I think this is okay. That said, I have not thoroughly vetted the new API in comparison to the old one. My feeling is that it seems to work with what we have (in that nothing breaks), and that in the worst case, we can add some things later that are missing. On the other hand, this is not my area of the library, so I won't merge at this time.

Thanks for looking at this - I am sorry reviewing wasn't easier!
bors merge

Pull request successfully merged into master.
